Change has been successfully merged by Cody Peter Mello

This is the only new test in this file. Everything else is just renaming to make it clear that they test IPv4 behaviour, so that when IPv6 tests are added, it's clearer what family a network belongs to.
The change to sorting in mock-moray.js exposed that there were two networks with the name "admin" in this test suite. This removes the one that shouldn't be the admin net.
The '(c)' should probably be nixed like the others you've been updating.
Should this variable be renamed to ip6addr as well?
I considered it, but felt that 'ipaddr' was easier to read and type, so I stuck with that.
Is there a way to perform this verification without accessing private fields in the CIDR?  If not, we should consider extending ip6addr appropriately.

I can imagine this verification being done in several different ways:

- A way to invoke createCIDR such that it throws when this condition is not true (i.e., when there are non-zero bits past those covered by the mask). I like the current behaviour of truncating, but I would like a way to check at user input validation points.
- A stable way to access the _addr field
- A method for accessing the _mask, or for converting prefix lengths into masks myself

The first one may be the best option. A function for converting prefix lengths into masks could also be good.

Could we document the 'expected' exception here.

I also think we should explicitly check that [a,b] are numbers (and maybe that they're numbers in the appropriate IP range?); if my reading is correct, the exception gets thrown from ip6addr when either a or b is neither an addr or a string parsable to an addr. If one or both is an  string that can't be parsed to an address (e.g., "undefined" or "null" or "[Object object]"), the comparison could lead to unexpected results.
I've written up a comment here explaining a bit more about the behaviour of this function. Let me know if it needs expanding.
